Wreckage found by a diver on the Great Barrier Reef is identified as an RAAF plane that crashed more than 70 years ago, killing all 11 people on board
Wreckage found in Cairns has been confirmed as World War II RAAF plane
RAAF Number 11 Squadron Catalina A24-25 crashed in February 1943
The wreckage was found 56km south of Cairns by a scuba diver in 2013
Catalina aircrafts were used to fly long-range missions during WWII

Catalina A24-25 11 aircrew were:
Wing Commander John William Daniell, 140, Age 26

Squadron Leader Eric Hamilton Barkley, 250281, Age 27

Global Elites Converge on Washington, DC, for Bilderberg Group Meeting
By Simon Kent
https://rayviolet.blogspot.com/2022/06/global-elites-converge-on-washington-dc.html

Global elites representing business, politics, big tech, media, and academia are now in Washington, DC, for the 68th annual meeting of the Bilderberg Group.

Among the 120 invitees this year publicly acknowledged by Bilderberg are Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla, Henry Kissinger, former CIA head David Petraeus, former Google CEO Eric Schmidt, Sen. Kyrsten Sinema (D-AZ), and CIA Director William J. Burns.

UK Member of Parliament Tom Tugendhat, chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee in the House of Commons is also present.

So too Canada Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland and Mark Carney, vice chair of Brookfield Asset Management who served as the governor of the Bank of Canada from 2008 to 2013 and the governor of the Bank of England from 2013 to 2020.

The conference, initially started by the Dutch royal family in 1954, is seen as the genesis for ideas ranging from free trade agreements like NAFTA to the creation of the European Union, as Fox Metro reports. Key topics acknowledged for discussion in D.C. include:

NATO Challenges
China+++

_source.content: Bilderberg Group Meets In Secret To Discuss "Disinformation"June 4, 2022Behind closed doors.Elites from the world of politics, media, Big Tech, business, and more, are in Washington DC for the 68th annual Bilderberg Group meeting.The Bilderberg Group first meeting was in 1954, the agenda being building back Europe following the Second World War. It was organized by Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, and was held at the Bilderberg Hotel located in Oosterbeek.The list of attendees is often secret, but the organizers have confirmed a few people attending this year's meeting, like former Google CEO Eric Schmidt, CIA Director William Burns, Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla, former CIA head David Petraeus, and Sen. Krysten Sinema (D-AZ). The Prime Minister for the Netherlands Mark Rutte is also in attendance, as well as Canada's Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland who this year ordered banks to freeze the accounts of civil liberties protesters.According to the Bilderberg website, the discussion in this year's meeting will include:1. Geopolitical Realignments2. NATO Challenges3. China4. Indo-Pacific Realignment5. Sino-US Tech Competition6. Russia7. Continuity of Government and the Economy8. Disruption of the Global Financial System9. Disinformation10. Energy Security and Sustainability11. Post Pandemic Health12. Fragmentation of Democratic Societies13. Trade and Deglobalisation14. _source.contentraw:
Bilderberg Group Meets In Secret To Discuss "Disinformation"

June 4, 2022

Behind closed doors.

Elites from the world of politics, media, Big Tech, business, and more, are in Washington DC for the 68th annual Bilderberg Group meeting.

The Bilderberg Group first meeting was in 1954, the agenda being building back Europe following the Second World War. It was organized by Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, and was held at the Bilderberg Hotel located in Oosterbeek.

The list of attendees is often secret, but the organizers have confirmed a few people attending this year's meeting, like former Google CEO Eric Schmidt, CIA Director William Burns, Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla, former CIA head David Petraeus, and Sen. Krysten Sinema (D-AZ). The Prime Minister for the Netherlands Mark Rutte is also in attendance, as well as Canada's Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland who this year ordered banks to freeze the accounts of civil liberties protesters.

According to the Bilderberg website, the discussion in this year's meeting will include:

1. Geopolitical Realignments
2. NATO Challenges
3. China
4. Indo-Pacific Realignment
5. Sino-US Tech Competition
6. Russia
7. Continuity of Government and the Economy
8. Disruption of the Global Financial System
9. Disinformation
10. Energy Security and Sustainability
11. Post Pandemic Health
12. Fragmentation of Democratic Societies

_source.contentraw:
Global Elites Converge on Washington, DC, for Bilderberg Group Meeting
6/3/2022 | Simon Kent
https://www.breitbart.com/politics/2022/06/03/global-elites-converge-on-washington-dc-for-bilderberg-group-meeting/

Global elites representing business, politics, big tech, media, and academia are now in Washington, DC, for the 68th annual meeting of the Bilderberg Group.

Among the 120 invitees this year publicly acknowledged by Bilderberg are Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla, Henry Kissinger, former CIA head David Petraeus, former Google CEO Eric Schmidt, Sen. Kyrsten Sinema (D-AZ), and CIA Director William J. Burns.

UK Member of Parliament Tom Tugendhat, chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee in the House of Commons is also present.

So too Canada Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland and Mark Carney, vice chair of Brookfield Asset Management who served as the governor of the Bank of Canada from 2008 to 2013 and the governor of the Bank of England from 2013 to 2020.

The Bilderberg Meeting is a forum for informal discussions about major issues. The meetings are held under the Chatham House Rule, which states that participants are free to use the information received, but neither the identity nor the affiliation of the speaker(s) nor any other participant may be revealed.

Thanks to the private nature of the Meeting, the participants take part as individuals rather than in any official capacity, and hence are not bound by the conventions of their office or by pre-agreed positions. As such, they can take time to listen, reflect and gather insights. There is no detailed agenda, no resolutions are proposed, no votes are taken and no policy statements are issued.

_source.content: This is how local government wastes your tax money....McCall, Idaho is a town of about 4000 residents....and take a look at the waste in the local government...The McCall-Donnelly School District will build new offices for district administrative staff costing upwards of $2 million.M-D trustees on Monday voted to move forward with plans to develop office space that includes five offices, a conference room and a 58-person meeting room.The current superintendent‚Äôs office at 120 Idaho St. in McCall would be torn down and the new facility built in the same location.The current building hold four offices and has a variety of problems, including undrinkable water, heating problems and mold.The new offices would host district administration, the Information Technology department and provide a space for school board meetings that are now held at McCall-Donnelly High School.The meeting room would include technology to assist in streaming board meetings online and videoconferencing.The IT department is currently hosted in a temporary building in the high school parking lot.Costs for the new building would be paid from a combination of the district‚Äôs capital improvement fund, capital project fund and federal forest fund which currently have about $2.5 million in total, M-D District Superintendent Eric Pingrey said.The federal forest fund is the district‚Äôs allocation from the Secure Rural Schools and Community Self Determination Act of 2000. The capital improvement fund is a board directed fund that consists of budget carryover and the capital construction fund is available to the district for miscellaneous improvement projects.Pingrey told trustees on Monday that there was ‚Äúzero need to go out to the community‚Äù for additional funding.The temporary building would likely be remodeled for classrooms after the IT department relocates, Pingrey said.
_source.contentraw:
This is how local government wastes your tax money....McCall, Idaho is a town of about 4000 residents....and take a look at the waste in the local government...


The McCall-Donnelly School District will build new offices for district administrative staff costing upwards of $2 million.

M-D trustees on Monday voted to move forward with plans to develop office space that includes five offices, a conference room and a 58-person meeting room.

The current superintendent‚Äôs office at 120 Idaho St. in McCall would be torn down and the new facility built in the same location.

The current building hold four offices and has a variety of problems, including undrinkable water, heating problems and mold.

The new offices would host district administration, the Information Technology department and provide a space for school board meetings that are now held at McCall-Donnelly High School.

The meeting room would include technology to assist in streaming board meetings online and videoconferencing.

The IT department is currently hosted in a temporary building in the high school parking lot.

Costs for the new building would be paid from a combination of the district‚Äôs capital improvement fund, capital project fund and federal forest fund which currently have about $2.5 million in total, M-D District Superintendent Eric Pingrey said.

The federal forest fund is the district‚Äôs allocation from the Secure Rural Schools and Community Self Determination Act of 2000. The capital improvement fund is a board directed fund that consists of budget carryover and the capital construction fund is available to the district for miscellaneous improvement projects.

Pingrey told trustees on Monday that there was ‚Äúzero need to go out to the community‚Äù for additional funding.

The temporary building would likely be remodeled for classrooms after the IT department relocates, Pingrey said.

_source.content: "On your path, dear ones, you must listen to the subtle guidance you receive: from your physical bodies, from your emotional bodies, from your higher Self, and from the many masters and angels that work with you. The heart is the spiritual center of the human being. Though you might receive information through your higher centers - in telepathic communications, for example - only in  moving this information  through the heart center does it have any real meaning for you. Then if will affect the physical and the emotional self, the human self that is calling out for assistance. The I AM presence is perfectly adept just as it is. It is the human self that is crying out for love. And it is the human self that must walk through the inner door of the heart, there to be greeted by the Christ, as I am the shepherd destined to guide you. I don't care if you know that it is I who fills you with love, but I do care that you are filled with love. It is my duty to melt your hearts, dear ones, to help you access your innate innocence and purity. It is there, and you  have never left it but only in your sophistications, and in your fears,  and in  your belief systems of lack and limitation. The opening of the heart center grants a special grace and presence and healing. And in this moment you may be able to feel my energies penetrating you in a healing way, filling your bodies. There is much more occurring here than meets the eye or the ear. If your heart centers are open, you can feel it. If your heart centers require more opening, I am working in that way. You have total freedom, my dear ones - freedom of manifestation, freedom of choice - and it is my pleasure and the pleasure of the Creator to watch you and to experience with you as you enjoy your freedom of manifestation. "On your path, dear ones, you must listen to the subtle guidance you receive: from your physical bodies, from your emotional bodies, from your higher Self, and from the many masters and angels that work with you. The heart is the spiritual center of the human being. Though you might receive information through your higher centers - in telepathic communications, for example - only in moving this information through the heart center does it have any real meaning for you. Then if will affect the physical and the emotional self, the human self that is calling out for assistance. The I AM presence is perfectly adept just as it is. It is the human self that is crying out for love. And it is the human self that must walk through the inner door of the heart, there to be greeted by the Christ, as I am the shepherd destined to guide you. I don't care if you know that it is I who fills you with love, but I do care that you are filled with love. It is my duty to melt your hearts, dear ones, to help you access your innate innocence and purity. It is there, and you have never left it but only in your sophistications, and in your fears, and in your belief systems of lack and limitation.

The opening of the heart center grants a special grace and presence and healing. And in this moment you may be able to feel my energies penetrating you in a healing way, filling your bodies. There is much more occurring here than meets the eye or the ear. If your heart centers are open, you can feel it. If your heart centers require more opening, I am working in that way. You have total freedom, my dear ones - freedom of manifestation, freedom of choice - and it is my pleasure and the pleasure of the Creator to watch you and to experience with you as you enjoy your freedom of manifestation. But it is also our duty to assist you in accessing the free choice to return to Source in a practical and real way, in a way that you have called ascension. And this can only be accomplished through giving yourself to Spirit and in allowing the heart opening."

Sananda, through Eric Klein

Eric Holcomb in response to a law passed by the General Assembly that allows legislative leaders to call an emergency session. Holcomb challenged the law on constitutional grounds.The law, known as House Enrolled Act 1123, authorized eight members of the Assembly, known as the Legislative Council, to call for an emergency legislative session when three criteria are met.Those criteria are the governor has declared a state of emergency the Legislative Council believes impacts the entire state, legislative action is needed to deal with the emergency, and a special session of the General Assembly is needed.The law passed April 5. Holcomb vetoed it almost immediately, but the veto was overridden by the legislature. Holcomb filed a lawsuit challenging the law three weeks later.The court‚Äôs decision affirmed Holcomb‚Äôs claim the legislature cannot call itself into a session outside the times specified by law. Emphasizing that their ruling had no bearing on the advisability of granting that power to the legislature, the case had been decided purely on constitutional grounds.Holcomb hailed the ruling in a statement, saying, ‚ÄúFrom the beginning, this case presented important procedural, statutory and Constitutional questions that only the courts could answer. Today, the Indiana Supreme Court has provided clarity and finality on these important issues. I appreciate the patience and humility Speaker Huston and Sen. Bray have shown throughout the entire process, of which I always sought to match. _source.contentraw:
Indiana Supreme Court sides with governor in separation of powers case

Justice conclude only the state‚Äôs governor may call the legislature into emergency session

JUNE 4, 2022
The decision, authored by Chief Justice Loretta Rush, found that by allowing a subset of eight lawmakers to call a special session, HEA 1123 violated the constitutional provision that the time of legislative sessions be ‚Äúfixed-by-law,‚Äù which would require a bill passed by both houses of the General Assembly. So, the legislature cannot determine the time of a legislative session unless it is actually in session.

The justices affirmed that ‚ÄúThis means that only the Governor has the constitutional authority to call a special session, i.e., one that is set at a time when the General Assembly is not in session,‚Äù and that HEA 1123 constituted an infringement on the doctrine of separation of powers.

The Indiana Supreme Court unanimously ruled Friday only the state‚Äôs governor may call the legislature into emergency session.

The case had been brought by Gov. Eric Holcomb in response to a law passed by the General Assembly that allows legislative leaders to call an emergency session. Holcomb challenged the law on constitutional grounds.

The law, known as House Enrolled Act 1123, authorized eight members of the Assembly, known as the Legislative Council, to call for an emergency legislative session when three criteria are met.

Those criteria are the governor has declared a state of emergency the Legislative Council believes impacts the entire state, legislative action is needed to deal with the emergency, and a special session of the General Assembly is needed.

The law passed April 5. Holcomb vetoed it almost immediately, but the veto was overridden by the legislature. Holcomb filed a lawsuit challenging the law three weeks later.

The court‚Äôs decision affirmed Holcomb‚Äôs claim the legislature cannot call itself into a session outside the times specified by law. Emphasizing that their ruling had no bearing on the advisability of granting that power to the legislature, the case had been decided purely on constitutional grounds.

Holcomb hailed the ruling in a statement, saying, ‚ÄúFrom the beginning, this case presented important procedural, statutory and Constitutional questions that only the courts could answer. Today, the Indiana Supreme Court has provided clarity and finality on these important issues. I appreciate the patience and humility Speaker Huston and Sen. Bray have shown throughout the entire process, of which I always sought to match. With this critical matter resolved, we‚Äôll continue focusing on building a prosperous state full of opportunity for all."‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶

Indiana Supreme Court sides with governor in separation of powers case

Justice conclude only the state‚Äôs governor may call the legislature into emergency session

JUNE 4, 2022
The decision, authored by Chief Justice Loretta Rush, found that by allowing a subset of eight lawmakers to call a special session, HEA 1123 violated the constitutional provision that the time of legislative sessions be ‚Äúfixed-by-law,‚Äù which would require a bill passed by both houses of the General Assembly. So, the legislature cannot determine the time of a legislative session unless it is actually in session.

The justices affirmed that ‚ÄúThis means that only the Governor has the constitutional authority to call a special session, i.e., one that is set at a time when the General Assembly is not in session,‚Äù and that HEA 1123 constituted an infringement on the doctrine of separation of powers.

The Indiana Supreme Court unanimously ruled Friday only the state‚Äôs governor may call the legislature into emergency session.

The case had been brought by Gov. Eric Holcomb in response to a law passed by the General Assembly that allows legislative leaders to call an emergency session. Holcomb challenged the law on constitutional grounds.

The law, known as House Enrolled Act 1123, authorized eight members of the Assembly, known as the Legislative Council, to call for an emergency legislative session when three criteria are met.

Those criteria are the governor has declared a state of emergency the Legislative Council believes impacts the entire state, legislative action is needed to deal with the emergency, and a special session of the General Assembly is needed.

The law passed April 5. Holcomb vetoed it almost immediately, but the veto was overridden by the legislature. Holcomb filed a lawsuit challenging the law three weeks later.

The court‚Äôs decision affirmed Holcomb‚Äôs claim the legislature cannot call itself into a session outside the times specified by law. Emphasizing that their ruling had no bearing on the advisability of granting that power to the legislature, the case had been decided purely on constitutional grounds.

Holcomb hailed the ruling in a statement, saying, ‚ÄúFrom the beginning, this case presented important procedural, statutory and Constitutional questions that only the courts could answer. Today, the Indiana Supreme Court has provided clarity and finality on these important issues. I appreciate the patience and humility Speaker Huston and Sen. Bray have shown throughout the entire process, of which I always sought to match. With this critical matter resolved, we‚Äôll continue focusing on building a prosperous state full of opportunity for all."‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶

card.description: The presence of a school resource officer and a few armed staff members can reduce casualties by 80% or more, according to one researcher.
card.title: Research shows armed teachers save lives

_source.content: Research shows armed teachers save livesJune 2, 2022 | Cam Edwardshttps://bearingarms.com/camedwards/2022/06/02/research-shows-armed-teachers-save-lives-n58998The idea of arming trained, volunteer school staff members to serve as a first line of defense against any targeted attack on students has been dismissed by Democratic lawmakers and teachers unions alike, but a majority of voters appear much more receptive to the idea. A new poll by the Trafalgar Group found almost 60% of voters believe that the absence of armed school staff members makes schools more dangerous, with just 30% disagreeing.More importantly, as we discuss on today‚Äôs Bearing Arms‚Äô Cam & Co, research into the idea bolsters the claims by supporters that having an armed presence on campus can save lives‚Ä¶ a lot of lives.Dr. J. Eric Dietz is the director of the Homeland Security Institute at Purdue University, and has been studying this issue for years with an eye towards reducing casualties and ending these active shooter incidents as quickly as possible. During today‚Äôs conversation, Dietz told me that computer modeling conducted by the HSI shows that two things can reduce fatalities in an active shooter situation on a school campus by more than 80%; the presence of a school resource officer who can engage the assailant, and 5-10% of school staff members who have been trained and are armed to protect kids in locked classrooms.The idea isn‚Äôt teachers would be roaming the hallways looking for the attacker. Under Dietz‚Äôs modeling, that‚Äôs left up to law enforcement, with the armed staff members sheltering in place with their students and taking action only if the door to their classroom (or library, or administrative office) is breached.Still, many educators want nothing to do with the idea.‚ÄúI went to college to become a teacher, not a law enforcement officer,‚Äù said Jourden Armstrong, a teacher for 15 years in Michigan. ‚ÄúCommonsense gun reform is an absolutely necessary component to curbing this uniquely American problem.‚ÄùShe also argued teachers would leave the profession in droves if these policy proposals were enacted. There was already a shortage of teachers around the US and the Covid-19 pandemic worsened the problem.‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared, my kids are scared, and I‚Äôm ready to walk away from a job I love because I feel absolutely powerless,‚Äù Armstrong said. ‚ÄúPowerless to protect myself, powerless to protect my students, and powerless to blood money that our legislators continue to accept because they put profit over people.‚ÄùEven if every gun in the United States was banned tomorrow that wouldn‚Äôt get rid of the problem of determined killers arming themselves and targeting innocent human lives. But we‚Äôre also not going to ban every gun, or even every modern sporting rifle, and not because lawmakers are ‚Äúputting profit over people.‚Äù
_source.contentraw:
Research shows armed teachers save lives
June 2, 2022 | Cam Edwards
https://bearingarms.com/camedwards/2022/06/02/research-shows-armed-teachers-save-lives-n58998

The idea of arming trained, volunteer school staff members to serve as a first line of defense against any targeted attack on students has been dismissed by Democratic lawmakers and teachers unions alike, but a majority of voters appear much more receptive to the idea. A new poll by the Trafalgar Group found almost 60% of voters believe that the absence of armed school staff members makes schools more dangerous, with just 30% disagreeing.

More importantly, as we discuss on today‚Äôs Bearing Arms‚Äô Cam & Co, research into the idea bolsters the claims by supporters that having an armed presence on campus can save lives‚Ä¶ a lot of lives.

Dr. J. Eric Dietz is the director of the Homeland Security Institute at Purdue University, and has been studying this issue for years with an eye towards reducing casualties and ending these active shooter incidents as quickly as possible. During today‚Äôs conversation, Dietz told me that computer modeling conducted by the HSI shows that two things can reduce fatalities in an active shooter situation on a school campus by more than 80%; the presence of a school resource officer who can engage the assailant, and 5-10% of school staff members who have been trained and are armed to protect kids in locked classrooms.

The idea isn‚Äôt teachers would be roaming the hallways looking for the attacker. Under Dietz‚Äôs modeling, that‚Äôs left up to law enforcement, with the armed staff members sheltering in place with their students and taking action only if the door to their classroom (or library, or administrative office) is breached.

Still, many educators want nothing to do with the idea.

‚ÄúI went to college to become a teacher, not a law enforcement officer,‚Äù said Jourden Armstrong, a teacher for 15 years in Michigan. ‚ÄúCommonsense gun reform is an absolutely necessary component to curbing this uniquely American problem.‚Äù

She also argued teachers would leave the profession in droves if these policy proposals were enacted. There was already a shortage of teachers around the US and the Covid-19 pandemic worsened the problem.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared, my kids are scared, and I‚Äôm ready to walk away from a job I love because I feel absolutely powerless,‚Äù Armstrong said. ‚ÄúPowerless to protect myself, powerless to protect my students, and powerless to blood money that our legislators continue to accept because they put profit over people.‚Äù

Even if every gun in the United States was banned tomorrow that wouldn‚Äôt get rid of the problem of determined killers arming themselves and targeting innocent human lives. But we‚Äôre also not going to ban every gun, or even every modern sporting rifle, and not because lawmakers are ‚Äúputting profit over people.‚Äù

This group of elite power brokers owns the media, they own the politicians, and, arguably, they own the world.

Nothing sinister at all about some of the largest purveyors of disinformation in the world meeting in secret to discuss possible world war with China and Russia, while plotting how to silence speech they consider ‚Äúdisinformation.‚Äù

The world‚Äôs ruling elite will meet in secret this week. No press will be allowed in, no one will be interviewed about it, and Bilderberg will not even register as a blip within the mainstream media‚Äôs radar.

This group of elite power brokers owns the media, they own the politicians, and, arguably, they own the world.

In attendance to this year‚Äôs meeting are war criminals like Henry Kissinger, Albert Bourla the CEO of criminal pharmaceutical company Pfizer, Head of the CIA William J Burns, the Secretary General of NATO, Jens Stoltenberg, GlaxoSmithKline CEO Emma Walmsley, Eric Schmidt the infamous former CEO of Google, and other heads of corporate media, foreign heads of state, and military officials. The elite group of power brokers made up of people who forced vaccines, lockdowns, and tyranny on the entire planet for the last two years.

Nothing sinister at all about some of the largest purveyors of disinformation in the world meeting in secret to discuss possible world war with China and Russia, while plotting how to silence speech they consider ‚Äúdisinformation.‚Äù

Bilderberg attendees must abide by Chatham House Rules, meaning that while participants can use the information received, they are barred from talking about any individual who may have steered their decisions.

In 2011, then-Congressman Ron Paul called for an investigation and noted that U.S. officials participating in the yearly gathering ‚Äî specifically Texas Gov. Rick Perry at the time ‚Äî were quite possibly breaking the law.

_source.contentraw:
So long trying to avoid controversy üçª here‚Äôs my thoughts.

I used to be the ‚Äúwhatever happens in your bedroom is your business‚Äù person. I used to be indifferent. But we went from ‚Äúour bedroom, our business‚Äù, ‚Äúwe just want to be able to marry each other‚Äù, ‚Äútwo consenting adults‚Äù to this. To mentally deficient men mostly nude, parading themselves in leather bondage to children. We now spend a whole month celebrating this behavior. ‚ÄúTrans youth‚Äù is a term unfathomable to the regular person just 10 years ago.

Therefore, I‚Äôm no longer tolerant.

I used to subscribe to the Black Lives Matter movement. I thought ‚Äúfor sure, I can see disparities in the treatment of minorities‚Äù, I believe in equality in law and for every man to have equal opportunity. As a Christian, I know Jesus died for all of us. But, then I saw the leaders mimicking Bolshevik/Marxist talking points, and realized there‚Äôs an agenda behind this movement. I then noticed the conversation go from being pro-minority, to being blatantly anti-White. You can scroll through Twitter and see thousands of posts still up calling for White Genocide.

Therefore, I‚Äôm no longer tolerant.

I used to advocate for sensible gun laws; mandatory training, age restriction, registration. But, the gun lobby went from ‚Äúrelax, no one wants to take your guns‚Äù, to ‚Äúwe want to restrict access to handguns and a ban on AR-15‚Äôs. If that doesn‚Äôt work, we‚Äôll tax ammo so high you won‚Äôt be able to buy it.‚Äù The best way to take over a nation is to disarm it‚Äôs people. United States Congressman Eric Swalwell even said ‚Äúthe US has a lot of nukes, and that it would be a short war‚Äù.

Therefore, I‚Äôm no longer tolerant.

I used to be pro-choice. I thought that the sensible idea is for the choice to belong to the woman. That‚Äôs freedom, right? I was wrong. I researched what actually happens during an abortion. I researched (and now witnessed) the stages of fetal development, when their heart beats, when they react to mom‚Äôs voice, when they can live viably outside the womb. I witnessed so many women coldly say that fetuses are nothing but parasites. That it‚Äôs the mother‚Äôs choice to terminate up to delivery. Some even advocate for post-birth termination.

Therefore, I‚Äôm no longer tolerant.

I could go on, but it‚Äôs unnecessary. If you didn‚Äôt see it before, you should start to see it now. The position I hold on most controversial subjects is the mainstream traditional position of every American since the founding of this country or before. If you think like me, you‚Äôre not crazy.

Everything I am and stand for is attacked daily, and it‚Äôs progressively (pun intended) getting worse, I can no longer be tolerant.

Because we‚Äôve seen what your ideas do, they create more murder.‚Äù‚ÄúDemocrats control the major cities that have the worst murder rates ‚Äî your ideas have been shown to get people killed,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúYou here for the murderers, the murderers in Chicago, in Philadelphia in these other major cities, because you‚Äôre wanting to do nationally, what is being done by Democrats in those big cities,‚Äù he said.His comments came after some Democrat Congress members, including Rep. ‚ÄòHow Dare You?‚Äô Republican Louie Gohmert Goes Scorched Earth On Democrats! Another republican with a set of BALLS!Republican Texas Rep. Louie Gohmert went off on Democrats in an emotional response after, he believed, they were insinuating the Republicans sided with murderers.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that it‚Äôs very effective for the children to have people on the other side of the aisle come in and accuse Republicans of being complicit in murder and that we put our right to kill over others‚Äô right to live,‚Äù he said during a Judiciary House Committee hearing on Thursday via video conference.

‚ÄúTo infer by rhetorical supposed questions: ‚ÄòWho are you here for? We must be here for the gunmen,‚Äô is an outrage,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHow dare you! You think we don‚Äôt have hearts?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just that when we look at the things that you‚Äôre doing, and you‚Äôre trying to do to America, we‚Äôve seen the carnage,‚Äù he argued.

‚ÄúWe care about people. We care about their lives, and lives have been so trivialized,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe care deeply. How dare you, how dare you, you arrogant people! Attributing murder to those of us that want to do things to stop it. Because we‚Äôve seen what your ideas do, they create more murder.‚Äù

‚ÄúDemocrats control the major cities that have the worst murder rates ‚Äî your ideas have been shown to get people killed,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYou here for the murderers, the murderers in Chicago, in Philadelphia in these other major cities, because you‚Äôre wanting to do nationally, what is being done by Democrats in those big cities,‚Äù he said.

_source.contentraw:
The final exam

Trying to get people "masked" was the first test. The second was trying to get them to roll up their sleeves for the jab. Many have failed both tests. Now comes the most important test ‚Äì the final exam, so to speak. It is the attempt to get them to hand over what has so far probably prevented anyone ‚Äî in the US ‚Äî from being forced at gunpoint to submit to masks and injections, Eric Peters writes .

They were able to get most people to put on that vile device called a ‚Äúmask‚Äù ‚Äì using the baton of deprivation of service, travel or work. But it was not a universal denial, as there were alternatives, including places that would serve or work with an "unmasked" person. Or they could work (and travel) on their own. It was uncomfortable not to submit to wearing the ‚Äúmask‚Äù ‚Äì but it wasn't that hard either.

And it was not forced.

So too with the serum-styled ‚Äúvaccines‚Äù that have been pushed by the government, with the help of the corporations and other ‚Äúprivate‚Äù companies that are no longer, in the sense that they are only allowed to operate if the government allows them to. say. And in what way. As such, they have become authorized agents of the government. Some ‚Äì like the makers of the serums being pushed ‚Äì use this symbiotic relationship to get the government to pressure people who work for these ‚Äúprivate‚Äù companies to take the serums they make, which they spend a lot of money on. earn by pushing them.

But no one was really forced to take these drugs, which are labeled as ‚Äúvaccines‚Äù. You could avoid the shops and restaurants that demanded it. You could quit your job, if your employer insisted - and find another job, instead of submitting to it.

You could refuse.

And there was little the government ‚Äî or the corporations that have become government agents ‚Äî could do about it. Other than refusing to ‚Äúserve‚Äù (or employ) you.

These were not the times that tested the soul of man.

But what will happen when it comes to the point where the government has all the weapons? And thus has the resources to force you to ‚Äúmask‚Äù ‚Äì as well as roll up your sleeve?

Sure, she has a lot of weapons right now. And she has shown that she is willing to use it when the opportunity arises. Better said, when she knows there won't be much resistance ‚Äì from people who also have guns.

The government does not like a fair fight. By the way, any more than the companies that have become authorized agents of the government, who prefer an unfair fight ‚Äì against potential competition ‚Äì by using the government to protect them from it, witness the way the large retail chains during the ‚Äúlockdowns‚Äù could use the government to close the doors of smaller, independent businesses to lure people through the open doors of their big chain stores.
- - -
Like in Australia and New Zealand, for example.

And as in China.
